article:
In epidemiology and statistics, an 'observational study' draws inferences about
the possible effect of a treatment on subjects, where the assignment of subjects
into a treated group versus a control group is outside the control of the
investigator. Porta M (editor). A
dictionary of epidemiology. 5th. edition. New York: Oxford University Press,
2008. This is in contrast with experiments, such as randomized controlled
trials, where each subject is randomly assigned to a treated group or a control
group before the start of the treatment.
